chapter.title: Common Tasks
chapter.para: This chapter contains information on common tasks.

sect2.title: Playing and Extracting Audio CDs
sect2.para:
When you put an audio CD in the drive Sound Juicer should start automatically. If you have an internet connection, it will also download the names of the tracks and display them in the player. Just click on play to listen to your music. You can also launch Sound Juicer from the menu by clicking
Applications Sound & Video Sound Juicer CD Ripper .

Sound Juicer can also extract (rip) your audio CDs to your hard drive. Just press Extract instead of Play and SJ will automatically begin to rip the CD into the Ogg Vorbis (.ogg) format. It can also rip into the high quality lossless .flac format, although the file sizes will be much larger.

sect2.title: Burning CDs
sect2.para: When you put a blank CD in the drive Ubuntu will ask if you want to burn an audio, photo or data CD. Simply choose which action you would like to do, then Ubuntu will launch the appropriate application. If you click Burn Audio CD will launch Serpentine which will allow you to add music files and burn them as a normal audio CD. You will also need to select the size of your media (21, 74, 80 or 90 minutes), Serpentine will warn you if you over-fill the CD.

To make a photo or data CD, click either Burn Photo CD or Burn Data CD. Ubuntu will launch the File Browser (Nautilus, which will allow you to add any file or folder you have permission to access. When you are happy with the layout click the Write to Disc. Ubuntu will then ask you to select the right drive to burn the CD in, and give you the opportunity to name the CD and select the write speed. Finally, click Write to create the new photo or data CD.

sect2.title: Playing and Organising Music Files
sect2.para: Ubuntu does not directly support the MP3 format, because it is restricted by patents and proprietary rights. Instead Ubuntu supports the Ogg Vorbis format out of the box, which is a completely free, open and non-patented format. Ogg Vorbis files also sound better then MP3 files of the same file size and support is available from many popular music players such as the iRiver and the Rio Karma (more information can be found here.).

You can still play your old MP3 files by installing 3rd party MP3 support, see this page on the Ubuntu Wiki for information on doing this. Installing support for other formats, such as Windows Media Audio (wma/wmv) and other patent encumbered formats can be found here on the Ubuntu Wiki also.

The default music application on your Ubuntu system is Rhythmbox, a music management and playback application that looks similar to iTunes. When you first start Rhythmbox, it will scan your home directory for any mp3 and ogg music you have and add it to the database.
The Cowbell ID3 tag editor can edit the metadata on your mp3 and other music files. To useCowbell:

sect1.para: Many video formats can be played in Ubuntu using free codecs found in the repositories. This includes formats such as MPEG and other common video formats. To install free codec support see .

sect2.title: Email
sect2.para: The Evolution groupware suite can handle all your email, contact lists, tasks and calendar needs. It also can act as a newsreader and also integrates with the Gnome panel clock, giving you one-click access to your task list.
Evolution can be launched by clicking Applications Internet Evolution Mail from the desktop menu system.
Alternatively the Mozilla Thunderbird email client is available. To install this popular email client, install the mozilla-thunderbird package.

To start Thunderbird, choose
Applications Internet Thunderbird Mail Client from the desktop menu system.

sect2.title: World Wide Web
sect2.para:
The powerful and secure Mozilla Firefox web browser is included in Ubuntu. Mozilla Firefox features tabbed browsing, pop-up blocking, in-built search facilities, live bookmarks and more. Also supported are popular plug-ins such as Java, Macromedia Flash, Macromedia Shockwave and Real Player just to name a few. Mozilla Firefox can be launched by clicking
Applications Internet Firefox Web Browswer from the desktop menu system.

listitem.para: Make sure the multiverse repository is enabled. (See )
Install the flashplayer-mozilla package with Add/Remove Applications (See )
The plug-in will be available the next time you start Firefox.

sect3.title: Gaim
sect3.para:
Gaim is the default instant messenger client in Ubuntu. With Gaim you can talk to people who use: AIM/ICQ, Gadu-Gadu, GroupWise, IRC, Jabber, MSN, Napster and Yahoo. The ability to use one client instead of multiple is a great benefit and allows you to have all of your buddies in one window so you can just click a name and talk. To start Gaim, choose
Applications Internet Gaim Internet Messenger from the desktop menu system.

sect2.title: Preventing the Ctrl-Alt-Backspace shortcut keys from restarting X

listitem.para: Make a backup copy of your existing /etc/X11/xorg.conf file. sudo cp /etc/X11/xorg.conf /etc/X11/xorg.conf_backup
Open /etc/X11/xorg.conf for editing. sudo gedit /etc/X11/xorg.conf
Add the following lines to the end of the file: Section "ServerFlags" Option "DontZap" "yes" EndSection
Save the edited file. (See for an example.)
The change will take effect the next time you log in to GNOME. If you want the change to take effect immediately, restart GNOME manually. (See .)
